metadata.title: Nano-shape varied cerium oxide nanomaterials rescue human dental stem cells from oxidative insult through intracellular or extracellular actions

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Full length article
Nano-shape varied cerium oxide nanomaterials rescue human dental stem cells from oxidative insult through intracellular or extracellular actions
Chinmaya Mahapatra, Rajendra K. Singh, Jung-Hwan Lee, Jieun Jung, Jung Keun Hyun, Hae-Won Kim
PII: S1742-7061(16)30670-5 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.actbio.2016.12.014 Reference: ACTBIO 4595

Nano-shape varied cerium oxide nanomaterials rescue human dental stem cells
from oxidative insult through intracellular or extracellular actions
Chinmaya Mahapatraa,b, Rajendra K. Singha, Jung-Hwan Leea, Jieun Junga, Jung Keun Hyuna,c, and HaeWon Kima,b,d,*
a Institute of Tissue Regeneration Engineering (ITREN), Dankook University, Republic of Korea
b Department of Nanobiomedical Science & BK21 PLUS NBM Global Research Center for Regenerative Medicine, Dankook University, Republic of Korea
c Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, College of Medicine, Dankook University, Cheonan, Republic of Korea
d Department of Biomaterials Science, College of Dentistry, Dankook University, Republic of Korea
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- *Corresponding author: Prof. H.-W. Kim (e-mail: kimhw@dku.edu; tel: +82 41 550 1926)
Abstract: Cerium oxide nanomaterials (CeNMs), due to their excellent scavenging properties of reactive oxygen species (ROS), have gained great promise for therapeutic applications. A high level of ROS often degrades the potential of stem cells in terms of survivability, maintenance and lineage differentiation. Here we hypothesize the CeNMs may play an important role in protecting the capacity of stem cells against the oxidative insult, and the suppression mechanism of ROS level may be dependent on the internalization of CeNMs. We synthesized CeNMs with different directional shapes (aspect ratios) by a pH-controlled hydrothermal method, and treated them to stem cells derived from human dental pulp at various doses. The short CeNMs (nanoparticles and nanorods) were internalized rapidly to cells whilst long CeNMs (nanowires) were slowly internalized, which led to different distributions of CeNMs and suppressed the ROS levels either intracellularly or extracellularly under the H2O2-exposed conditions. Resultantly, the stem cells, when dosed with the CeMNs, were rescued to have excellent cell survivability; the damages in intracellular components including DNA fragmentation, lipid rupture and protein degradation were significantly alleviated. The findings imply that the ROSscavenging events of CeNMs need special consideration of aspect ratio-dependent cellular internalization, and also suggest the promising use of CeNMs to protect stem cells from the ROS-insult environments, which can ultimately improve the stem cell potential for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine uses.
Keywords: Cerium oxide nanomaterials; nano-shape; stem cell survivability; cell internalization; intracellular damage

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Stem cells, including those multipotent and pluripotent are venerable to reactive oxygen species (ROS), and often significantly damaged under the ex vivo culture expansion environments and in the in vivo pathological conditions [1-3]. Preservation of the stem cell characteristics and the survivability under the ROS insult conditions is thus considered an important issue to gaining appropriate therapeutic potential of the stem cells for use in regenerative medicine.
Treatment of biomaterials particularly nanomaterials to stem cells has been a promising approach to modulate the cell functions, including the maintenance of cell proliferation and stimulation of differentiation into specific lineages [4-6]. For example, neural stem cells cultured with nanoparticles with different modifications (such as size and surface chemistry) alter their phenotypes in differentiation stage [7-10]. Moreover, mesenchymal stem cells have often been stimulated by the treatment of bioactive inorganic nanoparticles toward an osteogenic lineage [11-12]. Not only stem cells but many other tissue specific cells have also shown to be affected by the nanoparticles in their proliferation, migration, and maturation [13-15].
Therefore, the regulation of stem cell capacity, i.e., protection of the stemness and survivability from the ROS-inducing environments is considered possible through the action of nanomaterials. Among other nanomaterials, cerium oxide is considered one of the most intriguing compositions. The nanoparticle form of cerium oxide has the ability to scavenge ROS, and thus has shown significant cellular and sub-cellular effects [16-17]. Cerium oxide belongs to rare earth metal element in lanthanide series, and has variable oxidation state, i.e., Ce3+ and Ce4+, which combined with lattice structure defects, allows its action as oxidation and reduction catalyst in a continuous fashion (fenton-like reaction) [18], exhibiting unique biological behaviors [19-20]. For instance, cerium oxide nanoparticles treated to bone marrow stromal cells had substantial influences on cell migration and differentiation, and this was related with the reduced oxidative stress [21]. Neural cells, in response to cerium oxide nanoparticles, increased their survival, proliferation and differentiation due to the protection against endogenous peroxynitrite and Aβ-induced mitochondrial fragmentation [22]. Moreover, cardiac progenitor cells when dosed with cerium oxide nanoparticles preserved their proliferative capacity and cellular activity benefited from the reduction of oxidative stress [23].
Based on these studies, we hypothesize the cerium oxide nanomaterials (CeNMs) may be potentially used to improve the stem cell capacity such as proliferation and migration ability, and even protect their survivability particularly under the ROS insult environments. For this purpose, here we use human stem cells derived from dental pulp, as this cell source has been implicated to hold excellent therapeutic capacity in terms of high proliferative rate and profound differentiation
to different cell lineages including neural cells [24-27]. We particularly develop the CeNMs with different sizes, namely different aspect ratios, and this is implemented by the approach of a surfactant- and organic template-free pH-controlled hydrothermal method. The CeNMs developed with a range of shapes are treated to the human dental pulp stem cells at various doses. We aim to examine the effects of the treatment of CeNMs on the cell behaviors, including viability, migration, and the salvaging of subcellular components, and then to correlate the events with the cellular uptake and the ROS scavenging role of the nanomaterials. We consider this information will advance future development of CeNMs and their therapeutic uses for stem cell treatment in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, where the need for ROS control and scavenge is considered critical.

sections.heading: 2.1. Hydrothermal synthesis of various shaped cerium oxide nanomaterials
sections.text:
Different shaped CeNMs were prepared using a hydrothermal synthesis method, with a slight modification of previous works [28]. In a typical cerium oxide nanoparticle synthesis, 0.1 M of hexadecyltrimethylammonium (CTAB) and 1 M of cerium (IV) ammonium nitrate (Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6, 99.9 % purity) were dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water (DW) for 30 min under pH adjusted to 8.0 with ammonium hydroxide solution. After additional agitation for 60 min, the asobtained mixing solution was transferred into a bottle held in a stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 140°C for 24 h. As the autoclave cooled to a room temperature naturally, the precipitates were separated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and ethanol in sequence, and then dried in air at 80°C for 24 h to obtain the cerium oxide nanoparticle sample.
For the preparation of nanorod- and nanowire-shaped cerium oxide samples, supersaturated solutions were first prepared by mixing cerium (III) chloride (CeCl3•7H2O, 99.9%) in various molar concentrations (0.60, 0.35, and 0.12 M). Small amounts of NH4OH (28%) or HCl, used to adjust pH between 4.0 to 2.0, were dissolved in 50 mL of DW to form a solution ‘A’. Then, 0.04 mM of trisodium phosphate hexahydrate (Na3PO4•6H2O) was dissolved in 10 ml DW to form a solution ‘B’. The solution ‘B’ was introduced to the solution ‘A’, while vigorously stirring for 10 min. After additional agitation for 60 min, the as-obtained mixing solution was transferred into a bottle held in a stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 140°C for 24 h. After cooling, the precipitates were separated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and ethanol in sequence, and then dried in air at 80°C for 24 h to obtain the cerium oxide nanorods and nanowires. CTAB was removed from the synthesised CeNMs according to the method previously established [29]. The
CeNMs were dispersed in 60 mL of pure ethanol containing 500 mg of ammonium nitrate and stirred at 60°C overnight. The CeNMs were collected by a repeated process (x3) of centrifugation at 12000 rpm for 5 min and washing in deionized water, and then dried at 45°C for 24 h for further uses.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterizations of CeNMs
sections.text: The crystal structure was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD; Ragaku). The samples were scanned in the range of diffraction angle 2θ = 10-60° at a rate of 2° min-1 with a step width of 0.02° 2θ using Cu Kα1 radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA current strength. The nano-morphology of the samples was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-3000H) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL-7100). For the TEM observation, the aqueous suspension of the nanoparticles was drop-cast onto a carbon-coated copper grid, and the grid was air-dried at room temperature. Zeta (ζ) potential of the samples was measured using a Malvern Zetasizer (ZEN3600; Mlavern), at 25˚C in deionized water in triplicate. The size of samples was analyzed by a particle size analyzer (Zetasizer Nano ZS, Malvern Instruments, UK) based on a dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurement. Specific surface area were determined by nitrogen gas adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K using a Quadrasorb SI automated surface area and pore size analyzer (2SI-MP-9 Quantachrome). Samples were degassed under vacuum prior to analysis, and the degassing temperature was 100˚C with an outgas time of 4 h. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; AES-XPS ESCA 2000, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, MA) was performed in powder mode on carbon tape with a monochromatic Al Kα source in a cold field emission gun operated at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV at vacuum base pressure of 5×10−8 Torr. The deconvolution of Ce (3d) orbital satellite peaks was carried out using PeakFit (Version 4.1) software.

sections.heading: 2.3. Isolation and culture of human dental pulp stem cells
sections.text:
The human dental pulp tissues were obtained from normal third molars of patients with ages ranging from 19-to-25 years old after informed consent and approval by Institutional Review Board of the School of Dentistry in Dankook University, Republic of Korea. The isolation and culture protocols were according to the literatures established by Gronthos et al. [30]. In brief, the dental pulp isolated was cut into several pieces and then digested with incubation in a mixed solution of 3 mg/mL type I collagenase and 4 mg/mL dispase for 1 h at 37°C. A single cell suspension was obtained by passing the digested cells through a 70 µm cell strainer (BD biosciences). The cells were then seeded onto a tissue culture plate (100 mm2) at a density of 5 x 104 cells/well and grown with α-modified Eagle medium (α-MEM; HyClone, Thermo Scientific) supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS, HyClone,Thermo Scientific), 1% L-glutamax (Gibco), L-ascorbic acid 0.1 M (Gibco), 100 units/mL penicillin (Gibco), and 100 µg/mL streptomycin (Gibco). The cell fractions tightly adhered
to the plastic culture disc was considered for further experiments. Cells were maintained in the culture medium as mentioned above, and expanded when they reached approximately 70% confluence. Cells were cryo-preserved in liquid nitrogen at passage 4, and were thawed for further experiments after expansion at passage 5. The population of cells isolated was characterized by a flow cytometry. Surface markers positive for the mesenchymal stem cells (CD73, CD105 and CD106) as well as those negative for them (CD34 and CD45) were analyzed. For this, the cells grown at near confluence in 6 well-plates were disaggregated with accutase (Invitrogen), washed twice with PBS, and then resuspended to 1 x 105 cells/ml. The cells were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 15 min, treated with 0.2% Triton X100 for 5 min and blocked with 1% BSA. The cells were then probed with primary antibodies against goat anti-CD105 and - CD73 and rabbit anti-CD106, -CD34, and -CD45 antibody (Santa Cruz) at 1:100 dilution for 2 h. The cells were then incubated with FITC-labelled goat secondary anti-goat, rabbit antibodies (Santa Cruz) at 1:100 dilution at RT for 2 h in dark, after which they were washed 3 times with PBS and kept in ice for FACS analyses. Data were acquired using sterile clean capped 15 ml FACS tube (BD Bioscience) for 1 × 104 events using a Flow Cytometer (BD FACS Calibur), and then analyzed using a Cell Quest-Pro software (BD Biosciences).

sections.heading: 2.4. Treatment of CeNMs to stem cells and the viability assay
sections.text:
All the CeNMs were freshly prepared from stock solutions (10 mg/mL) and then sonicated in a culture medium for 30 s in ice before the addition to cell cultures. The dental pulp stem cells were first adhered to the culture plates at a density (4 × 103 cells/well) in 96 well plates for 24 h, and then the CeNMs were treated and then cultured for appropriate time periods for assays.
For the cell viability assay, the stem cells were treated with different types of CeNMs at varying doses (0, 10, 20, 40, 80, 160, and 320 µg), and then cultured for 24 h. After culture, the cell viability was analyzed by a cell counting assay kit (CCK-8, Dojindo). Briefly, CCk-8 solution was added to a working solution at 1:10 ratio, and then reacted for 2 h. After this, the medium was gathered for the measurement of an optical density at 450 nm using a microplate reader (Biorad).

sections.heading: 2.5. Cell migration study by an in vitro gap closure model
sections.text:
For the in vitro cell migration study, the cells were seeded at 5 x 104 cells/ml onto each well of 6 well-plates. When the cells reached a confluence, the cell proliferation was blocked by the treatment of 100 µl mitomycin C solution (10 µg/mL in DMEM, Sigma) for 2 h [31], and then an interval gap was made by using a 200 µl pipette tip to gently scratch in one direction which was checked under an optical microscope as modified protocol mentioned elsewhere [32]. The
nanomaterial concentration of 40 µg/ml was used for the migration test, which was based on the cell viability assay. Then, the cells were treated with 40 µg/ml of various types of CeNMs, and then cultured for different periods of up to 24 h. After the cultures, cells were washed with warm PBS 3 times to eliminate any non-adherent cells. The cell images at each time point were captured by a phase contrast microscope (Olympus, X-71), and the gap closure was quantified by the number of cells present in the gap.

sections.heading: 2.6. In vitro ROS-insult conditions using H2O2
sections.text: To enable the ROS-generating environments in vitro, the H2O2-conditioning assay was employed. From a trial and error test, the concentration of H2O2 was determined at 50 and 100 µM. First, the stem cells were plated at 4 × 10 3 cells/well in 96 well-plates and then were treated with different types of CeNMs at varying concentrations (0, 10, 20, 40, 80, 160, 320 µg). After 24 h of culture, the medium was washed 3 times with HBSS buffer, and then treated with 50 or 100 µM H2O2 solution for 30 min.

sections.heading: 2.7. Cell viability and live/dead cell assay under H2O2 condition
sections.text:
After the treatment of CeNMs at varying concentrations, the cell viability was measured by CCK assay. For this, cells were treated with CCK-8 reagent, as described in Section 2.4. As a control group, cells treated only with 100 µM H2O2 solution for 30 min were used.
The live-dead assessment of cells was also carried out. For this, cells (1 × 105 cells/ml/well) were seeded in 12-well culture plate and after 24 h of exposure to varying concentrations (20, 40, 80 g/ml) of CeNMs, 100 µM H2O2 was treated for 30 min. After this the culture medium was washed 3 times with DPBS and incubated in 2 µM calcein-AM and 4 µM PI (Invitrogen) for 30 min, and then followed by an observation by confocal microscopy (Zeiss 700 LSM). Live and dead cell were distinguished by conversion of non-fluorescent calcien-AM to fluorescent dye by intracellular esterase enzyme in living cells and propidium iodide (PI) dye uptake by dead cells. As a negative control, cells without the treatment of CeNMs or H2O2 were used. As a positive control, cells treated with 0.2% triton X-100 for 15 min were used.

sections.heading: 2.8. Cellular imaging
sections.text:
The cultured cells for 24 h were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and washed with PBS 3 times. The permeabilization was performed with 0.01% triton X-100 for 5 min. The blocking was carried out with PBS containing 1% BSA (Sigma Aldrich) and 0.01% Na-azide for 30 min at 37oC. The actin filaments were stained with Alexa fluro-555 phalloidin (Invitrogen) at 1 µg/mL after incubation at 37oC for 1 h. The nuclei were stained with DAPI (Invitrogen) at 1 µg/mL for
5 min. After the staining, the cells were washed with PBS 3 times and mounted with VICTASHIELD (H-1000, Vector Labs.) for the observation by confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM; Zeiss-700).

sections.heading: 2.9. FITC-labelled CeNMs and the cellular uptake
sections.text:
The CeNM internalization to cells was analyzed by a flow cytometry, and in order to do this, the nanomaterial surface was functionalized with (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), which allows for the link of FITC molecules to the surface by charge-charge interactions [33]. For this, 10 mg of the CeNMs were dispersed in 20 ml of anhydrous dimethylformalhehyde (DMF). A solution of 20 µl APTES diluted in 200 µl DMF was added to the nanomaterial suspensions, sonicated, and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The modified CeNMs were collected by a centrifugation, washed several times in DW followed by a vacuum drying to obtain fine powders suitable for the cellular experiments. The FITC conjugation to CeNMs was confirmed by measuring the fluorescence intensity of the solution at an emission wavelength of 495 nm and then referring to a standard curve obtained from various concentrations of FITC. Moreover, the chemical status of the nanomaterials was analyzed by XPS, as described in Section 2.2.
The stem cells were seeded at 5 × 105 cells per well in 6-well plates and allowed to adhere for 24 h. To determine the intracellular uptake of CeNMs, the cells were incubated with 40 µg/ml FITC-labelled CeNMs in DMEM medium for 24 h. After this, the cells were washed with PBS and then fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde. The cells were then permeabilized with 0.01% triton X-100 for 5 min, and blocked with 1% BSA and 0.01% Na-azide at 37°C for 30 min. For cell imaging, the FITC-labelled CeNMs and the cell nuclei counter-stained with DAPI (Invitrogen) were visualized under fluorescent microscope (Olympus X-71). The z-stack images of cells were obtained to visualize internalization of FITC-labelled CeNMs using confocal LSM700 (Carl Zeiss). Images taken at every 20 s comprise 30 stacks of maximum projection for z-stack under a 3-color configuration mode (488 nm for FITC, 555 nm for Rode, and 420 nm for DAPI). The z-stack images were converted into 3D projection images by the orthogonal tool in ZEN 2009 software to view the FITC-labelled CeNMs (green) internalized on xz- and yz-planes. Moreover, the fraction of cells positive for FITC signals was analyzed by a flow cytometry. The treated cells were washed 3 times with PBS, and data were acquired for 1 × 104 events by using a BD FACS Caliber. The cells positive for the signals were quantitatively determined by using a BD CellQuest Pro software.
2.10. Ultrastructural imaging by TEM
Transmission electron microscope (TEM) studies were carried out to observe the internalization of CeNMs. After treatment of 40 µg/mL to 1 x 105 cells for 24 h, the cells were fixed for 15 min in 0.1 M PBS solution containing 2.5% glutaraldehyde (Merck, Kenilworth, NJ) and 4% paraformaldehyde (1:1 ratio). They were then post-fixed with 1% osmium tetroxide (Polysciences, Warrington, PA), dissolved in PBS for 2 h, and dehydrated in a gradually ascending series (from 50 to 100%) of ethanol (Merck) and infiltrated with propylene oxide. Specimens were embedded using the Poly/Bed 812 Embedding Kit (Polysciences) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Sections of ~50 nm-thick were initially prepared and stained with toluidine blue (Sigma) for observation under a light microscope. Sections were double-stained each with 4% uranyl acetate (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Hatfield, PA) and 0.2% Raynolds lead citrate (Fisher, Carlsbad, CA) for 20 min and 10 min, respectively. Stained sections were cut by Leica EM UC7 (Leica Microsystems, Vienna, Austria) with a diamond knife (Diatome) and transferred onto copper and nickel grids. All the sections were observed on TEM (JEM-1011, JEOL) at the acceleration voltage of 80 kV.

sections.heading: 2.11. Measurements of ROS scavenging
sections.text:
The H2O2 induced ROS measurement was performed using H2DCFDA according to the manufacturer's protocol (Invitrogen). In brief, each 96-well plate was seeded with 5 × 103 cells/well and allowed to adhere for 24 h. Different concentrations of CeNMs (0, 20, 40, 80 and 160 µg) were added, and then after 24 h, H2O2 was treated to cells for 30 min. The culture medium was removed and then the cells were loaded with 5 µM H2DCFDA diluted in HBSS for 30 min at 37 °C. Cells were then washed three times with HBSS, and the fluorescence intensity (excitation at 485 nm and emission at 530 nm) was measured using a microtiter plate reader (Tecan, Infinite M2000).
The fluorescence live-imaging of cells was also conducted by CLSM (Zeiss LSM700) in a live imaging chamber maintained at 37oC with 95% humidity and 5% CO2. Phase contrast images of the cells along with ROS-positive intracellular green fluorescence signals were captured with a consecutive frame every min for a period of 1 h.

sections.heading: 2.12. Protein carbonylation
sections.text:
The cells were grown to a confluence in a 6-well culture plate for 24 h prior to treatment with CeNMs. Thereafter, H2O2 (100 µM) was treat for 30 min prior to washing in HBSS buffer (GIBCO, Invitrogen). The cells were washed 3 times with PBS and scrapped to collect cell pellet in Eppendorf tube. The cell lysate was extracted by adding cell lysis RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.6, 150 mM NaCl, 1% deoxycholate, 0.1% SDS, and 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) on ice and sonication for 5 min. The cell lysate was centrifuged at 13,000 rpm at 4oC for 20 min. The supernatant was
collected for further analysis. Equivalent amount of proteins determined by Bradford assay was analyzed for carbonylation through OxyBlot Protein Oxidation Detection Kit (Millipore), following the manufacturer’s instructions. In brief, the protein concentration was determined by using a modified Bradford method (Sigma). The whole cell lysates with equalized protein concentrations were derivatized with 2, 4- dinitrophenyl hydrazine (DNPH). The derivatized proteins were neutralized and separated by SDS-PAGE. The separated proteins were immunostained using rabbit antiDNP antiserum (1:150) and goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated to HRP (1:300). The bands were developed by chemiluminescence (Advansta, WesternBrightECL) and observed in LAS MINI 4000 (GE Healthcare).

sections.heading: 2.13. Lipid peroxidation
sections.text: The cell lysate was harvested and isolated as mentioned previously. The amount of lipid peroxidation was analyzed through OxiSelect TBARS Assay Kit (Millipore), following the manufacturer’s instructions. In brief, the cell lysate was incubated with 1% thiobarbituric acid (TBA) for 1 h at 90oC. The samples were centrifuged at 13,000 rpm for 5 min and supernatant fraction was quantified in black 96-well opaque bottom plates. The fluorescence intensity was measured by a plate reader (Tecan, Infinite M2000) at 544 nm excitation and 590 nm emission.

sections.heading: 2.14. Assessment of DNA damage
sections.text: The 10,000 cells were cultured on cell culture slide (SPL Life science, South Korea). The CeNMs were added and then H2O2 (100 µM) was treated, as mentioned previously. The cells were fixed with 4% formaldehyde and washed 3 times with PBS and blocked with 0.2% BSA with 0.05% TritonX-100 for 30 min. After washing 3 times with PBS, cells were incubated with anti-ϒH2AX rabbit antibody (Abcam) for 1 h. Secondary antibody detection was performed by Alexa488-conjugated anti rabbit antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology). Images were acquired using confocal microscope (Zeiss LSM 600).

sections.heading: 2.15. Statistics
sections.text: Data are presented as the mean ± one standard deviation. Statistical comparisons were made using the Student’s t-test. P < 0.05 or 0.01 was considered to be statistically significant.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. CeNMs are hydrothermally synthesized with various shapes and properties
Among the various forms possible to produce, here we focus on the development of CeNMs with different shapes (aspect ratios). For this, we prepared supersaturated Ce solutions at varying pH values from 2.0 to 8.0, and applied hydrothermal treatment at 140°C for different times. The morphologies of the prepared CeNMs were examined by high resolution SEM and TEM (Fig. 1a). The electron images provide direct information on the size and typical shape of the nanomaterials grown by the different experimental conditions. Cerium oxide nanoparticles (termed ‘CeN’), produced at pH 8.0 with the use of cerium nitrate as a precursor and CTAB as a surfactant, showed uniform-sized nanomaterial form [34]. The cerium oxide nanocrystal morphology was dramatically changed depending on pH, cerium salt, and reducing agent Na2PO4. For the generation of elongated morphologies (nanorods and nanowires) [35], the cerium chloride was used as the cerium precursor. The synthesis of nanorod/nanowire was begun by adjusting the pH < 4.5 wherein salt was dissolved. When the Na3PO4 was used, the nanorod form was produced well at pH lower than 4.5; however, a higher Na3PO4 concentration gave rise to the formation of CePO4 phase [36], so the salt concentration was maintained at 0.04 mM. Further formation of Ce(OH)3 phase was observed; which, although important for the crystal nuclei stability and the thermodynamically favourable crystal growth and ripening via Oswald mechanism [37], was removed when heated to 400°C for 4 h, resulting in pure CeO2 phase. Under this crystal formation mechanism, the nanorod and nanowire forms with different crystal elongations could be obtained while optimizing the pH and cerium precursor concentrations, i.e., small sized nanorod (termed ‘CeS’) at 0.60 M and pH 4.6, medium-sized nanorod (termed ‘CeM’) at 0.35 M and pH 3.4, and highly elongated nanowire (termed ‘CeW’) at 0.12 M and pH 2.0.
The average dimensions of the CeNMs, as measured from the TEM images (from at least 100 particles), are summarized
in Table 1. While CeN showed near-spherical particles with an aspect ratio of 1.31 (length ∼25 nm, width ∼19 nm), the
aspect ratio for CeS was 3.6 (length ∼180 nm, width ∼50 nm), and that of CeM was 11.2 (length ∼280 nm, width ∼25
nm). The CeW showed an aspect ratio of as high as 21.4 (length ∼600 nm and width ∼28 nm). The DLS measurement
showed a similar trend but higher values than TEM, due to the possible nanomaterial aggregation and the dynamic scattering in aqueous media [38]. As the particle aspect ratio increased the surface area measured by BET decreased substantially; 228.5 m2/g for CeN down to 8.2 m2/g for CeW. The ζ-potential values of CeNMs were all positive (+18.4 ∼ +24.5 mV), and the increase in aspect ratio slightly increased the ζ-potential.
The XRD patterns confirmed that the phase of all CeNMs was only cubic fluorite cerium oxide (JCPDS card no. 81- 0792) (Fig. 1b). We next analyzed the oxidation status of the CeNMs. The XPS analysis of samples revealed complex multi-peaks in particularly dominating Ce(3d) region with 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 orbital, and these complex peaks were
deconvoluted to enable the measurement of peak areas and thus the analysis of the Ce3+ and Ce4+ contents (Fig. 1c). It was observed that the Ce4+ content was higher than Ce3+ in CeN (74% Ce4+), whereas the Ce3+ content was dominant in other nanomaterials (Ce3+ ≈ 60-75%). It has also been reported that the Ce4+ was prevalent in Ce oxide nanoparticles
prepared through a similar hydrothermal processing in alkaline conditions [39]. However, the elongated forms of CeNMs were produced herein in acidic conditions for crystal growth in a preferred direction, because the Ce3+ present at surface was reasoned to enable the decoration of surface with hydroxyl ions for nucleation which could further promote the formation of nanowires or nanorods at lower pH [36]; as a result, high contents of Ce3+ could accumulate at the surface of elongated cerium oxides prepared at acidic conditions. As previously reported, Ce4+ demonstrated higher catalase mimicking activity and this was reasoned for the intracellular ROS scavenging role and the enhanced cellular behaviours [21-22]. The BET-measurement revealed the surface area of the CeNMs; CeN (228.5 m2 g−1) > CeS (92.5 m2 g−1) > CeM (15.6 m2 g−1) > CeW (8.2 m2 g−1). Moreover, the surface charge properties of the CeNMs, as measured by the ζ-potential analysis, showed highly positive-charges with a slight increase with increasing the aspect ratio (+18.4, +19.4, +23.1, and +24.5 mV, for CeN, CeS, CeM, and CeW, respectively), and this is considered to be related with the synthesis conditions, i.e., pile-up of more protons in more acidic conditions.

sections.heading: 3.2. CeNMs are highly compatible to stem cells and even enhance migration ability
sections.text:
Using the CeNMs tailored with different-shapes (aspect ratios) we next investigated the viability of stem cells derived from human dental pulp. The observation of cellular viability or toxicity and the determination of safe dosage are critical for the therapeutic applications of nanomaterials [40]. We treated the four different-shaped CeNMs to stem cells over the concentration range of up to 320 µg/ml, and then the cell viability was monitored up to 7 days by the CCK assay (Fig. 2a). After the treatment for 1 day, there was no significant toxicity observed for all the CeNMs over the concentration range tested, rather, the CeNMs (particularly CeN) were observed to enhance the cellular viability [41]. The initial ROS levels generated by dental stem cells (even though at small concentrations) can be regulated by the treated CeNMs, resulting in stimulated mitochondrial activity. Further, the observation for longer culture periods of 3 and 7 days also showed good cell viability by the CeN, CeS, and CeM treatment. Interestingly, the CeW showed slight toxic effect only at day 3, but this was recovered again at day 7. The reason for this was possibly due to that the CeW were internalized slowly and thus might trigger cells to experience a level of mild toxicity during this time course. In fact, it was reported that mesoporous silica-based nanomaterials with high aspect ratio also exhibited toxic effect when compared to those
with low aspect ratio [42]. Similarly, cerium oxide nanomaterials with higher aspect ratio showed higher toxicity in THP1 cells due to a membrane damage, as demonstrated by LDH assay [36]. However, the cellular toxicity of CeW was temporal only at day 3, mainly related with its cellular internalization process, i.e., the cells recovered the viability with further culturing. The fluorescence image of cells was then revealed (Fig. 2b). Cells showed no morphological differences associated with the treatment of CeN, CeS, and CeM during the culture periods; however, for the case of CeW particularly at higher concentrations the cellular morphology appeared to be more elongated, with profound directional extensions. This cell shape is also considered to reflect the dimensional character of the CeW that are sensed by the cells, one of the interesting phenomena that may need further studies. The results demonstrated well the excellent in vitro cellular viability of the developed CeNMs over a wide concentration range, a prerequisite for further use of the CeNMs in therapeutic purposes.
Next, we investigated the migration behaviors of cells with the treatment of CeNMs. In vitro scratched gap model was
constructed and the gap closure due to a cell migration was monitored (Fig. 3a). The treatment of 40 µg/ml CeNMs enhanced the cell migration significantly when the cells migrated toward the gap were quantified (Fig. 3a). While all the CeNMs enhanced the migration initially, CeN showed the most significant and sustained effect over the culture period.
The migration result is considered to be similar to that of cell viability observed at 40 µg/ml CeNMs. This improvement of cell migration by the cerium oxide nanoparticles has also been reported in osteoblasts and MSCs, and reasoned to the higher catalytic activity of the nanoparticles [21]. The involvement of cerium oxide in the rapid and effective wound healing has also been implicated in vivo [15]. Therefore, the CeNMs developed herein proved their potential uses in stimulating cellular migration ability when directly treated to cells. The migration ability of stem cells is of special importance for cell transplantation and therapeutic purposes as they have to migrate properly to the targeted disease and wound sites without a functional loss [15, 43-44].

sections.heading: 3.3. Stem cells take up CeNMs at different rate depending on the aspect ratio
sections.text:
As implicated in the study on cellular toxicity and morphological feature, the CeNMs were thought to internalize into the stem cells. To examine this phenomenon, we labelled the nanomaterials with FITC, and the FITC-fluorescence images were captured. To ensure that the number of fluorescent molecules labelled on each kind of CeNMs was similar, the
concentration of FITC molecules used was varied considering the surface area of the CeNMs. The stable conjugation of FITC to CeNMs was confirmed by the optical absorbance measurement (Supplement data, Fig. S1) [33, 45-47]; free FITC molecules were removed almost completely while strongly conjugated FITC remained onto the CeNMs stably at least for up to 3 days in a medium.
The FITC-labelled CeNMs were incubated for 24 h and the population of cells positive for the fluorescence signal was analyzed by FACS (Fig. 4a). Results at 24 h showed the CeNMs except CeW were effectively internalized to cells; 93.02% for CeN, 99.86% for CeS, and 96.76% for CeM. In contrast, the CeW showed very low internalization level (1.39%). We considered this slow internalization might be related with the highly elongated morphological trait. Longer cultures of the cells with CeW for 48 h and 72 h, however, resulted in substantial increase in cellular internalization; 65.88% and 93.69%, for 48 h and 72 h, respectively. The results clearly demonstrated slow yet time-dependent cellular internalization of CeW. The fluorescence images of cells taken up the CeNM were visualized by confocal microscopy at 24 h (Fig. 4b). While the cells treated with CeN, CeS, and CeM showed high fluorescence signals, those with CeW had little positive signals, reflecting well the FACS results. We further analyzed the cellular uptake of CeNMs through zstack imaging (Supplementary data, Fig. S2). While the CeN and CeS were mostly found inside of cells (cytosol) at 24 h, the CeW were shown to internalize partially at 24 h and then substantially thereafter. In fact, when we analyzed the chemical status of CeN and CeW conjugated with FITC as the representative samples by XPS, their Ce4+ and Ce3+ population changed slightly while maintaining the dominant oxidation status, i.e., in CeN, the Ce4+ as a major from 74% (before) to 84% (after FITC), and in CeW, the Ce3+ as a major from 59% (before) to 67% (after FITC), suggesting the influence of FITC-related oxidation status change on cellular uptake might not be significant.
This time-dependent slow cellular internalization of CeW is considered to explain the previous cell viability change and morphological trait, i.e., an abrupt down in cell viability at day 3 with a further recovery at day 7 might be due to the cellular internalization process that takes some period, and the internalized nanowires might alter the cell shape into a more elongated form. It is further considered that the internalization of CeW might be eased during the course of several doubling periods, since the cellular uptake of nanomaterials is known to be greatly enhanced by the cellular division [48]. The human dental pulp stem cells are known to have doubling time of ~18 h. A fraction of long nanowires bound to the cell surface receptors without being penetrated into a cell might undergo internalization during the cell mitosis. In fact, the cellular internalization is known to be governed by many materials factors, including the size, aspect ratio, elasticity, and surface chemistry [49-51]. For the CeNMs used in this study, the main parameter might be the aspect ratio. Regarding this, the nanoparticle form with the smallest aspect ratio (CeN) is considered to endocytosed easily while the
rod-type (CeS and CeM) also allows the internalization in a relatively favorable manner due to their sizes (even the long axis) at least smaller than a few hundred nanometers - many rod-type nanomaterials with high aspect ratios have been shown to experience spontaneous entry inside cells via a membrane penetration [36]. On the other hand, the nanowire form, due to its excessively long axial dimension (over 500 nm), might make it difficult and take more time and energy for the cells to adopt through a normal internalization process. For the case of other nanowires or nanotubes with high aspect ratios like iron oxide nanowires, nickel nanowires, and carbon nanotubes, such a slow cellular uptake (even over days) has also been noticed [52-55]. The nanowires oriented only (near) perpendicular to the plasma membrane were inferred to be taken up by the cells, perforating and diffusing the lipid bilayer without causing a substantial cell death [56-57].
The TEM ultrastructural images of cells that took up the CeN and CeW were visualized (Fig. 4c). The CeN were mostly found in endosomes as also previously reported, where the CeN endocytosed through clathrin- and caveolae-mediated processes [58]. The CeN localized in endosomes can exhibit significant oxidase activity of ROS in endosomes, resulting in ROS scavenging effect at whole cellular level [16-17, 41]. For the case of CeW, most were found within lysosome and some fractions were also observed in the cytosol, with the latter particularly for the case of bundled nanowires. While the single CeW length is approximately 500-600 nm, which is though less than the lysosomal size (as estimated to be 0.7-1.2 µm) [59-60], the bundled CeW can exceed the size of over a few micrometers, which possibly leads to the lysosomal damage, when present in the cytosol [36]. The sign of cytotoxicity of CeW particularly at higher concentration with prolonged culture period (72 h) can thus be interpreted based on this TEM result.
Along with the aspect ratio, the oxidation status of the CeNMs can also be considered because one recent study has reported the Ce4+ state was more favorable than the Ce3+ state for the human MSCs’ uptake [21], thus the CeN may be superior to CeW in the internalization capacity. At the time of 24 h following the treatment, it is thus considered that most of the CeN, CeS, and CeM were internalized to cells, whilst most CeW were present outside of the cells, possibly on the cell membrane surface, waiting for further cellular uptake. Due to the different location of the CeNMs depending on their aspect ratio, the way of their roles to be played in the ROS consumption might thus be somewhat different, which will be discussed in the following section.
3.4. CeNMs suppress the ROS generation of stem cells
Based on the results that the CeNMs exerted in the cellular viability and migration capacity in normal cell culture conditions, we considered their possible significant roles in the modulation of ROS levels under the ROS-insult environments. Some previous studies have also proved the ROS scavenging effects of the cerium nanoparticles [17, 19, 20, 41]. Here we designed an in vitro ROS-generating condition by the H2O2-treatment of cells. The endogenous ROS level produced by the cells was measured by the fluorescence intensities of the reaction products within cells (Fig. 5a). The exposure of cells to 100 µL of H2O2 for 30 min generated ROS significantly, to the level over twice the case of normal cells (without H2O2). However, when the cells were treated with CeNMs for 24 h, the ROS generation was significantly suppressed. The suppression in ROS level was the most significant in CeN, and was dose-dependent. The intracellular expression of ROS by the CeNMs treatment was live-imaged within a short time period of 60 min (supplementary files in Fig S3). Representative images framed at 20 min (shown in Fig. 5b) revealed the ROS green
signals were significantly attenuated in 40 µg/ml CeNMs-administered cells with respect to the H2O2-treated positive control.
Collectively, all the CeNMs significantly suppressed the ROS level generated by cells under the H2O2-insult environment. We consider this phenomenon is the result of ROS scavenging actions of CeNMs either intracellularly or extracellularly, and is related with the internalization event of the CeNMs. The possible mechanism of the event is schematically illustrated in Fig. 5c. In terms of cellular internalization rate, CeW and others (CeN, CeS, and CeM) are considered to be different; the former is slow, taking days whilst the latter is fast, taking only hours. Thus, at the early phase CeW are mostly present at the extracellular space (or outer surface) whilst others are primarily in the intracellular compartments. The H2O2 treated can enter into cells to evoke endogenous production of ROS, like peroxides, superoxide, hydroxyl radical, and singlet oxygen; here the CeN, CeS, or CeM present inside of cells can effectively scavenge those endogenous ROS levels. On the other hand, the CeW existing on the cell surface can interact with molecules primarily at the extracellular space, thus can down the level of H2O2 molecules and/or consume the ROS molecules released from the cells, which eventually decreases the ROS levels related with cells. While the ROS scavenging site of both groups of CeNMs is different (intracellular vs. extracellular), the resultant cellular ROS level can both become down-regulated effectively. In particular, the finding that the CeW, even not being internalized to cells but present on their surface initially, can modulate ROS levels extracellularly with good cell compatibility, supports the possible potential for in vivo uses as a mediator of cells and extracellular environments where significant oxidative stress is engaged in [44]. Of course, with time (after days), the CeW can also internalize to scavenge intracellular ROS levels.

sections.heading: 3.5. CeNMs rescue cell survivability by protecting cellular components (protein, lipid, and DNA) against oxidative
sections.text:
insult
Having confirmed the effects of CeNMs on the substantial suppression of ROS levels generated in human dental stem cells, we next sought to analyze the efficacy in cellular survivability. The exposure of 50 µM and 100 µM of H2O2 for 30 min was shown to be highly detrimental to cells, resulting in cell survivability down to 50-60%; however, the CeNMstreated cells were shown to recover the survivability to a great degree in a dose dependent manner (Fig. 6a). When dosed with CeNMs over 160 µg/ml, the cell survivability became levelled to the positive control (w/o treatment of H2O2), and even higher than the control for some sample groups, suggesting the treatment of CeNMs (over certain doses) was sufficient to protect the stem cells against the ROS insulted by the H2O2 exposure. The live/dead cell stain images reflected the cell survivability results, showing most cells were alive in the groups with high-dosed CeNMs; however, many cells were dead stained when exposed to H2O2 without the treatment of CeNMs (Fig. 6b). Particularly the low rescuing effect of cellular viability in CeM observed at the highest dose (320 µg/ml) might be due to combined reasons, i.e., the lowest Ce4+/Ce 3+ ratio and the special bundling effect, and for the latter case, the 200 nm of nanorod (as in the CeM) was proposed to be a critical length that could lead to bundling due to van der Waals and dipole-dipole forces [36], which however needs further study.
Further, to consolidate the CeNMs role in cellular rescue from H2O2 mediated oxidative insult we analyzed key intracellular components: i) DNA fragmentation, ii) lipid peroxidation, and ii) protein oxidation. Over expression of these illustrates various pathological conditions and aging of cells. First, the administration of CeNMs was shown to prevent the DNA double stranded breaks (DSBs), which known as the main cause of DNA damage, by staining phosphorylated histone, H2AX gamma (Fig. 7a). The number of stained foci (in green spots) and damaged nucleus became substantially increased when exposed to H2O2, which however, prevented significantly in the CeNMs-treated cells. Next, the lipid peroxidation was quantified by the MDA production (Fig. 7b). The applied CeNMs were highly effective in rescuing lipid from peroxidation upon exposure to H2O2 in a similar fashion to the effect in DNA fragmentation. Lastly, we quantified the levels of 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazine (DNPH) binding to carbonyl groups in protein, which explains the degraded nature of cellular proteins. The Western blot result (Fig. 7c) showed the exposure of H2O2 resulted in high oxidization of a whole protein in cells; however, the CeNMs-treated cells were significantly rescued from the oxidation of proteins. Collectively, the findings demonstrated the administration of CeNMs increased the human stem cell
survivability under oxidative stress through the cytoprotective roles in rescuing DNA damage, lipid peroxidation, and protein oxidation. Lastly, we briefly assessed the preservation of dental stem cell phenotypes that might be altered due to the ROS control of the CeNMs. CeN was used for the representative test sample as this type has shown the most effective ROS scavenging role in the cells studied. FACS results (supplementary data, Fig. S4) showed the initial cells were mostly positive for CD73 (99.2%), CD105 (98.6%) and CD106 (95.8%), but largely negative for CD34 (1.19%) and CD45 (0.44%), confirming that a major cell population isolated showed the characteristics of MSCs. When the CeN was treated, the cells were shown to preserve the characteristic MSC(+) markers (CD73; 99.86 %, CD105; 99.66 % and CD106; 97. 68 %) together with little expression of MSC(-) markers (CD34;1.38 % and CD45; 3.30 % ).
Based on the results, the CeNMs may be useful to improve the applicability of dental stem cells for regenerative medicine, through the increased proliferation and migration ability, and long term survivability, particularly under the oxidative stress conditions, and the more in-depth studies remain as to in vitro differentiation and in vivo functions using stem cell based therapeutic models in the future.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
CeNMs with various directional morphologies (CeN, CeS, CeN, and CeW) were successfully produced by means of a pH-controlled hydrothermal process. The developed CeNMs were highly compatible to stem cells from human dental pulp and were even supportive for the cell migration under normal culture conditions. Depending on the morphological difference of CeNMs, the intracellular penetration rate was found to be distinctly divided, i.e., slow for CeW whilst rapid for CeN, CeS, and CeM, which resulted in different distribution of the CeNMs with time. For this reason, the ROS scavenging actions of CeNMs occurred either extracellularly or intracellularly, both of which but ultimately contributed to lowering the ROS levels generated in cells and to rescue the key cellular components such as protein, lipid and DNA. As a result, the cells treated with CeNMs could be effectively protected from the H2O2-exposed ROS insult, preserving the survivability and possibly the potency in regenerative medicine.
Acknowledgements: This work was supported by the grants from the National Research Foundation, Republic of Korea; Priority Research Centers Program (No. 2009-0093829) and Global Research Lab Program (GRL: No. 2015032163).
